Doug Daniels
2020-03-11 14:41:53

Sorry if this is misunderstanding Cucumber/Gherkin/BDD, I'm trying to follow the Gherkin features defined for The Ray Tracer challenge book: https://pragprog.com/book/jbtracer/the-ray-tracer-challenge

e.g. ```Feature: Tuples, Vectors, and Points

Scenario: A tuple with w=1.0 is a point Given a ‚Üê tuple(4.3, -4.2, 3.1, 1.0) Then a.x = 4.3 And a.y = -4.2 And a.z = 3.1 And a.w = 1.0 And a is a point And a is not a vector When I run `godog` it produces code that looks to be based on regexp that parses each digit as a `\d` and also seems to incorrectly capture the negative sign, resulting in weird go code. func aTuple(arg1, arg2, arg3, arg4, arg5, arg6, arg7, arg8 int) error { return godog.ErrPending }

func FeatureContext(s **godog.Suite) { s.Step(^a ‚Üê tuple\((\d+)\.(\d+), -(\d+)\.(\d+), (\d+)\.(\d+), (\d+)\.(\d+)\)$, aTuple) s.Step(^a\.x = (\d+)\.(\d+)$, ax) s.Step(^a\.y = -(\d+)\.(\d+)$, ay) ... }`` Is there a way to structure this or havegodog` generate code using Cucumber expressions: https://cucumber.io/docs/cucumber/cucumber-expressions/

I would have expected something like: ```func aTuple(arg1, arg2, arg3, arg4 float64) error { return godog.ErrPending }

func FeatureContext(s **godog.Suite) { s.Step(^a ‚Üê tuple\({float}, {float}, {float}, {float}\)$, aTuple) s.Step(^a\.x = {float}$, ax) s.Step(^a\.y = {float}$, ay) ... } ... }```

pragprog.com
The Ray Tracer Challenge: A Test-Driven Guide to Your First 3D Renderer by Jamis Buck | The Pragmatic Bookshelf
Original URL: https://pragprog.com/book/jbtracer/the-ray-tracer-challenge
Doug Daniels
2020-03-11 14:44:16

Or is godog just meant to provide guidance on matching feature expressions, it's possible for me to just manually write the FeatureContext myself?

lonnblad
2020-03-11 14:55:49

Hey @Doug Daniels, yes, you can write your own FeatureContext.

The autocreated code is just to give you a suggestion to get going, but it could probably be better at matching float expressions.

Regarding matching floats, if you take this feature: ```Feature: godog

Scenario: fractional godogs
    Given 0.5 godogs```

You could have a test file like this: ```package godog_test

import ( "github.com/cucumber/godog" )

func godogs(arg1 float64) error { return nil }

func FeatureContext(s **godog.Suite) { s.Step(^(\-**\d+\.\d+) godogs$, godogs) }`` Regarding Cucumber expressions like{float}`, I believe there is no such support as of now

üíØ Doug Daniels

lonnblad
2020-03-18 05:41:01

*Thread Reply:* I believe an issue with using something like testify is that it doesn‚Äôt produce an error for you, so you would need to do that by yourself.

You can definitely do as @Gem suggests and use some of their underlying functions, but you would basically have to implement something like this code to achieve assert.Equal : ```if !assert.ObjectsAreEqual(expected, actual) { diff := diff(expected, actual) expected, actual = formatUnequalValues(expected, actual)

return fmt.Errorf("Not equal: \n"+
    "expected: %s\n"+
    "actual  : %s%s", expected, actual, diff
)

}```

lonnblad
2020-03-18 05:43:05

*Thread Reply:* if you only want to achieve simpler assertions, but use the standard formatters, I guess this is what you would do

2020-03-18 09:18:16

Matt
2020-03-26 14:04:19

Hey folks! I saw the deprecation notice for BeforeFeature() and was trying to switch to BeforeSuite() but I was having trouble determining the lifecycle of a suite. Is a Suite created for every feature file or is it the entire collection of features and steps from all the files mashed into one?

lonnblad
2020-03-27 14:23:56

*Thread Reply:* Hi @Matt, sorry for not getting back to you earlier.

We are currently discussing how we want to handle this going forward with the changes we are making to Concurrency.

In short, the suite lifecycle we are looking at, is that the suite is the global context for the full test run encompassing all features and scenarios. BeforeSuite hooks would be executed once before all features and AfterSuite hooks would be executed once after all features.

Today, this is the case for non-concurrent runs.

Let me know if you have further questions! When I have more details regarding the updated lifecycle, I will post it in this thread as well.

BR Fredrik

Matt
2020-03-27 15:12:37

*Thread Reply:* Nice! Thanks for the response.

So, part of what we're using GoDog for is restoring a kubernetes cluster to a clean state. Each feature kind of muddies that up, so the BeforeFeature() function was pretty useful for us. How would you go about solving that under the new paradigm? I have a feeling we probably just need to think of our testing in a bit of a different way, but I figured some direct feedback would be good too üôÇ

lonnblad
2020-03-27 15:15:49

*Thread Reply:* Could you elaborate a bit on why you do cleanup for each feature and not for each scenario?

Matt
2020-03-30 14:20:40

*Thread Reply:* We're testing some stuff in Kubernetes. After each feature we shut down the cluster, create a new one, and then start a new feature test.

Every scenario would be far too often and Suite would be not enough (because some of our tests include some global state).

Matt
2020-03-30 15:22:33

*Thread Reply:* We're also open to anything we can do differently if we just need to change some of our testing strategy

mpkorstanje
2020-04-02 13:39:46

*Thread Reply:* Alright. I understand.

By design it is assumed scenarios are intended to be independent - or atleast that you want them to be independent. When external resources are involved it is assumed that these can be clearly identified so tags can be used to do the setup/tear down of these.

In your case this is all a bit more muddled. You may indeed have to rethink your testing strategy a bit or look for a work around. The most practical one that I can think of right now is that you run your feature files individually.

Tom Sasser
2020-04-14 07:00:22

So here is what I had to do:

  1. Move the old project repo out of the way since it wasn‚Äôt in $GOPATH/src
  2. Upgraded Go to 1.14.2 since I was on an old version anyway. Likely not the issue.
  3. Remove the entire $GOPATH dir. mv ~/go ~/go.old
  4. Recreate $GOPATH dirs. mkdir -p $GOPATH/src $GOPATH/bin $GOPATH/pkg
  5. cd $GOPATH
  6. git clone the repo into $GOPATH/src. cd src; git clone PATH.git
  7. Reinstall godog GO111MODULE=on go get <a href="http://github.com/cucumber/godog/cmd/godog@v0.8.1">github.com/cucumber/godog/cmd/godog@v0.8.1</a>
  8. Install a few other libs as needed.
  9. dep init
  10. dep ensure
  11. godog -t "@myTag"

Hi folks, I'm currently working on scaling my team's use of Godog from a proof-of-concept so that we can use it in favor of our old Java back end. Wanted to say hello and express my appreciation for the project -- I've found it well-built and easy to learn and use so far.

I was noticing some of the earlier conversation about using assertion frameworks such as Testify, and it didn't seem like anyone had landed on anything they liked for it. I found an approach today that seems to work fine, so I thought I'd share it. I ran into some unrelated issues that will sidetrack me, so I haven't proven this out extensively yet, but it seems like it should do what's needed. It depends on creating a wrapper that implements Testify's TestingT interface, which seems designed for exactly such things. Not sure if I'm missing more of what people were going for here somehow, but I expect this to work for my needs.

*Thread Reply:* So what I found is that there was a problem with the modules. go list ‚Ä¶. showed many problems. I think there is some sort of conflict between importing DATA-DOG/godog and cucumber/godog for different projects. I will get to the part that I don‚Äôt understand in a bit.

The procedure I did to finally get the gears-flows-api-test working was this:

  1. Wipe out the entire ~/go tree and recreate ~/go/{pkg|bin|src}
  2. brew uninstall dep glide go
  3. brew install dep glide go
  4. cd ~/go/src
  5. git clone the repo
  6. cd ~/go/src/gears-flows-api-test
  7. GO111MODULE=on go get github.com/cucumber/godog/cmd/godog@v0.8.0
  8. dep ensure (do not do dep init)
  9. godog -t ‚Äú@version‚Äù

I have this code setup in my godog:

Tom Sasser
2020-06-29 10:31:12

Is there a way to make these apply to some tags but not others? For example, if my feature file has tags @foo, @bar, and @baz, how would I have each run only on foo and exclude bar and baz?

lonnblad
2020-06-29 14:03:05

Hi @Tom Sasser, you would have to use if or switch statements

Since you are on v0.8.**, you need to convert the interface to either Scenario or ScenarioOutline and then get the tags. ```import "github.com/cucumber/godog/gherkin"

func beforeScenario(v interface{}) { var tags []**gherkin.Tag

if s, ok := v.(**gherkin.Scenario); ok {
    tags = s.Tags
}

if s, ok := v.(**gherkin.ScenarioOutline); ok {
    tags = s.Tags
}

for _, tag := range tags {
    switch tag.Name {
    case "foo":
        beforeFooScenario()
    case "bar":
        beforeBarScenario()
    default:
    }
}

}```

Fulvio Carvalhido
2020-07-06 06:11:33

lonnblad
2020-07-06 06:50:43

Hi @Fulvio Carvalhido

Yes, you will still be able to create external formatters, the interfaces and functions that exist in the godog package will continue to work from there. I would like to add some more documentation on how you would create your own, but it hasn‚Äôt been a priority of mine, since I don‚Äôt use an external formatter as of today.

If you want to look at how it probably will be in v0.11.0, I would check this package. https://pkg.go.dev/github.com/cucumber/godog/formatters?tab=doc

But I wouldn‚Äôt recommend working against master, unless you are okey with potential breaking changes, since things might change around before the release. We try to not break legacy between releases without marking it as deprecated during one release.

lonnblad
2020-07-06 11:59:07

@Fulvio Carvalhido I made this example: https://github.com/cucumber/godog/blob/dfc3e04478dff951d75b68563ad1d9a64f6b11e2/_examples/custom-formatter/custom.go

_examples/custom-formatter/custom.go
<pre><code>package customformatter import ( "io" "&lt;a href="http://github.com/cucumber/messages-go/v10"&gt;github.com/cucumber/messages-go/v10&lt;/a&gt;" "&lt;a href="http://github.com/cucumber/godog"&gt;github.com/cucumber/godog&lt;/a&gt;" ) func init() { godog.Format("custom", "Custom formatter", customFormatterFunc) } func customFormatterFunc(suite string, out io.Writer) godog.Formatter { return &amp;amp;customFmt{suiteName: suite, out: out} } type customFmt struct { suiteName string out io.Writer } func (f **customFmt) TestRunStarted() {} func (f **customFmt) Feature(**messages.GherkinDocument, string, []byte) {} func (f **customFmt) Pickle(**godog.Scenario) {} func (f **customFmt) Defined(**godog.Scenario, **godog.Step, **godog.StepDefinition) {} func (f **customFmt) Passed(**godog.Scenario, **godog.Step, **godog.StepDefinition) {} func (f **customFmt) Skipped(**godog.Scenario, **godog.Step, **godog.StepDefinition) {} func (f **customFmt) Undefined(**godog.Scenario, **godog.Step, **godog.StepDefinition) {} func (f **customFmt) Failed(**godog.Scenario, **godog.Step, **godog.StepDefinition, error) {} func (f **customFmt) Pending(**godog.Scenario, **godog.Step, **godog.StepDefinition) {} func (f **customFmt) Summary() {} </code></pre>

lonnblad
2020-07-07 02:36:08

*Thread Reply:* https://github.com/cucumber/godog/issues/194

kargakis (https://github.com/kargakis)
#194 godog steps linting
<p>Is there any easy way to lint source code to catch duplicate godog steps? We have been bitten a couple of times because godog matches steps defined in golang to features files and developers copy/paste golang steps across tests thinking the receiver defined in the new step will be used when it's the receiver in the step that godog matches first that is actually going to be used.</p>

The answer is, we cannot handle retrieving value from .yaml file inside .feature file. We have to do it inside the Go code.

#174 Added Support for Cucumber JSON Report's File Embeddings

Aslak Helles√∏y
2020-09-01 13:31:22

‚Ä¢ https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm/blob/f6fb4160d4f3298918fd58f36cc256aeb25ed8f9/java/src/main/java/io/cucumber/java/Scenario.java (public API) ‚Ä¢ https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm/blob/6006deb48c3052934695e608340fd23cf5742b7c/core/src/main/java/io/cucumber/core/runner/TestCaseState.java#L68-L104 ‚Ä¢ https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-js/blob/master/src/runtime/attachment_manager/index.ts ‚Ä¢ https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/516738c89ba8b5c5cc43273567a512cadc92770c/lib/cucumber/formatter/message_builder.rb#L43-L65 In the Java/Ruby/JavaScript implementations, the attach function/method is defined on an object that Cucumber (optionally) passes to Before hooks. User code can then hold a reference to that object and invoke the attach function in a stepdef or After / AfterStep hook. The implementation of the attach function writes an Attachment message to the message stream. That's a protobuf object defined here: https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/blob/master/messages/messages.proto#L349-L391

Aslak Helles√∏y
2020-09-01 13:32:18

Formatters can then do what they want with the attachment. For example the HTML formatter will render it. The progress formatter will ignore it.

Aslak Helles√∏y
2020-09-01 14:42:41

Regarding HTML formatters. There are a bunch of third party ones out there. There is now an official one too! https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/blob/master/html-formatter/README.md

I think it would be awesome if godog adopted it as a built-in formatter.

html-formatter/README.md
<pre><code># Cucumber HTML Formatter This is a cross-platform formatter that produces a HTML report for Cucumber runs. It is built on top of [cucumber-react](../cucumber-react/javascript) and works with **any** Cucumber implementation with a `message` formatter that outputs [cucumber messages](../cucumber-messages). This formatter is built-in in cucumber-ruby and cucumber-jvm, but for other Cucumber implementations that haven't yet done so, the `cucumber-html-formatter` can also be used as a standalone tool. ## Installation Using NPM: npm install -g cucumber-html-formatter Using Docker: docker pull cucumber/cucumber-html-formatter:latest ## Usage Using NPM: cat cucumber-messages.ndjson | cucumber-html-formatter --format ndjson &amp;gt; index.html Using Docker: cat cucumber-messages.ndjson | docker run --interactive --rm cucumber/cucumber-html-formatter:latest --format ndjson &amp;gt; index.html ## Obtaining `cucumber-messages.ndjson` If you're using a Cucumber version with a `message` formatter, pass `--format messages:cucumber-messages.ndjson` to it. </code></pre>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber">cucumber/cucumber</a>
Aslak Helles√∏y
2020-09-01 15:02:50

I created an issue: https://github.com/cucumber/godog/issues/339

aslakhellesoy (https://github.com/aslakhellesoy)
#339 Implement HTML formatter
<p>Cucumber-JVM and Cucumber-Ruby now implement a <code>html</code> formatter based on the <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/tree/master/html-formatter">standard html formatter</a>.</p> <p>The implementations are here:</p> <p>Java:</p> <p>‚Ä¢ <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/blob/master/html-formatter/java/src/main/java/io/cucumber/htmlformatter/MessagesToHtmlWriter.java">MessagesToHtmlWriter.java</a> (library) ‚Ä¢ <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-jvm/blob/main/core/src/main/java/io/cucumber/core/plugin/HtmlFormatter.java">HtmlFormatter.java</a> (Cucumber-JVM formatter)</p> <p>Ruby:</p> <p>‚Ä¢ <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/blob/master/html-formatter/ruby/lib/cucumber/html_formatter.rb">html_formatter.rb</a> (library) ‚Ä¢ <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber-ruby/blob/master/lib/cucumber/formatter/html.rb">html.rb</a> (Cucumber-Ruby formatter)</p> <p>TypeScript:</p> <p>‚Ä¢ <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/cucumber/blob/master/html-formatter/javascript/src/CucumberHtmlStream.ts">CucumberHtmlStream.ts</a> ‚Ä¢ Not yet integrated into Cucumber-js</p> <p>It would be great to port the library to Go (in the monorepo) and then use it from within godog!</p>

if st := m.Run(); st &gt; status {
    status = st
}

os.Exit(status)

}

func runGodog(opts godog.Options) (status int) { var buf bytes.Buffer

opts.Format = "cucumber"
opts.Output = &amp;buf

fmt.Println("call API: TestStarted")

status = godog.TestSuite{
    Name:                "godogs",
    ScenarioInitializer: InitializeScenario,
    Options:             &amp;opts,
}.Run()

fmt.Println("call API: ", buf.String())

return

}```

Does anyone know how to access scenario context from within a Step if concurrency is enabled?

Lewis Cowles
2020-11-04 03:53:32

Lewis Cowles
2020-11-04 03:57:57

Being able to non-serially run tests is something I desire, that I thought README.md was saying was possible when talking about concurrency.

My plan was to use the scenario Id or Name as a key to a Map, so that concurrent scenario's do not need to worry about collisions with the context defined at suite or scenario level. I guess making the api object at scenario level might allow me to have that without a map now I think about it... I'll try it

Lewis Cowles
2020-11-04 04:01:27

I guess if this works I would not have suite state contain scenario state...

Lewis Cowles
2020-11-04 04:29:08

Okay so I am certain I have this working now. I'll blog about it by weekend (hopefully)

Lewis Cowles
2020-11-04 04:36:05

key parts were

```func InitializeScenario(ctx **godog.ScenarioContext) { state := ScenarioState{} ctx.BeforeScenario(state.beforeEach) ctx.AfterScenario(state.afterEach)

ctx.Step(`^I ask for a price for (\d+) KWh usage$`, state.iHaveKWhUsage)
ctx.Step(`^I should find It costs (\d+) annually$`, state.iShouldFindCostAnnually)

}``` The perhaps not obvious

```type ScenarioState struct { response string }

func (scenarioState* ScenarioState) beforeEach(scenario *godog.Scenario) { // ... }

func (scenarioState* ScenarioState) afterEach(scenario *godog.Scenario, err error) { // ... }

func (scenarioState** ScenarioState) iHaveKWhUsage(kwh int) error { // .... }

func (scenarioState** ScenarioState) iShouldFindCostAnnually(kwh int) error { // .... }```

2020-11-04 04:37:35

I've not quite worked out how to get all three to play together scenario, suite and step hooks, but I might get there

Felix Cornelius
2021-01-14 02:28:33

Hello everyone, at my company we‚Äôre using godog heavily to test our microservice environment for a while now. We started building a little convenience wrapper on top of it which comes with some generic reusable contexts for grpc, events, placeholders, etc. Now to my question: Has anyone here fiddled around with reusability a little and found an elegant solution to prevent that reused feature contexts re-register steps/hooks that have already been registered before? Example: ‚Ä¢ Service context a and service context b both reuse the generic stateful context c (eg. placeholder substitution functionality). ‚Ä¢ Now service context a wants to use some steps from service b so it registers its feature context on its own godog.Suite (we‚Äôre still on v0.9). ‚Ä¢ Now two instances of feature context c are created and steps/hooks are registered twice on context a , resulting in hooks being executed twice. We‚Äôve ‚Äúsolved‚Äù this so far by making the reusable contexts that need state into singletons which is obviously a poor choice, especially when it comes to parallelism. I thought about creating a DI-like context registry which holds information about registered contexts for each suite, but I don‚Äôt want to make things overly complex. Has anyone been here before?

@lonnblad thanks a lot for your work. Would love to hear your two cents on this, although it‚Äôs not an urgent matter.

lonnblad
2021-01-14 10:53:30

*Thread Reply:* in v0.10.0 we also changed both the way hooks are setup and the way concurrency works

now you create hooks either for the whole test-run or for a given scenario and instead of executing features concurrently, we execute the scenarios concurrently

https://github.com/cucumber/godog/blob/master/release-notes/v0.10.0.md

release-notes/v0.10.0.md
<pre><code>We are excited to announce the release of godog v0.10.0. Here follows a summary of Notable Changes, the Non Backward Compatible Changes and Deprecation Notices. The full change log is available [here](&lt;https://github.com/cucumber/godog/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#v0100&gt;). Notable Changes --------------- ### Context Initializers The current Suite initializer will be removed and replaced by two new initializers, one for the Test Suite and one for the Scenarios. The ****TestSuiteContext**** Initializer will be executed once for the execution of the full TestSuite. ```go // These are the hooks that can be configured for the TestSuite. func (ctx **TestSuiteContext) BeforeSuite(fn func()) func (ctx **TestSuiteContext) AfterSuite(fn func()) </code></pre> <p>The <strong><em>*ScenarioContext</em></strong>* Initializer will be executed before every Scenario.</p> <pre><code>// These are the hooks that can be configured for a Scenario. func (ctx **ScenarioContext) BeforeScenario(fn func(sc **Scenario)) func (ctx **ScenarioContext) AfterScenario(fn func(sc **Scenario, err error)) func (ctx **ScenarioContext) BeforeStep(fn func(st **Step)) func (ctx **ScenarioContext) AfterStep(fn func(st **Step, err error)) // Registers a step definition for a Scenario. func (ctx **ScenarioContext) Step(expr, stepFunc interface{}) </code></pre> <h3>Formatter Concurrency</h3> <p>All builtin formatters now support concurrency.</p> <h3>Scenario Concurrency</h3> <p>Using the new Initializers, godog will now execute scenarios concurrently instead of features.</p> <h2>Non Backward Compatible Changes</h2> <h3>Hooks</h3> <p><code>BeforeFeature</code> and <code>AfterFeature</code> hooks are now removed since the deprecation in <a href="./v0.9.0.md">v0.9.0</a>.</p> <h2>Deprecation Notices</h2> <h3>Run and RunWithOptions</h3> <p><code>Run</code> and <code>RunWithOptions</code> are now considered deprecated and will be removed in <code>v0.11.0</code>.</p> <p><code>godog.Run(suiteName string, initializer func(**Suite))</code> will be replaced by:</p> <pre><code>godog.TestSuite{ Name: suiteName, TestSuiteInitializer: InitializeTestSuite, ScenarioInitializer: InitializeScenario, }.Run() </code></pre> <p><code>godog.RunWithOptions(suiteName string, initializer func(**Suite), opts Options)</code> will be replaced by:</p> <pre><code>godog.TestSuite{ Name: suiteName, TestSuiteInitializer: InitializeTestSuite, ScenarioInitializer: InitializeScenario, Options: &amp;amp;opts, }.Run() </code></pre> <h3>Suite Initializers</h3> <p>The <code>Suite</code> is now considered deprecated and will be removed in <code>v0.11.0</code>.</p> <p>Initializers that use <code>**godog.Suite</code> like this:</p> <pre><code>func FeatureContext(s **godog.Suite) { s.BeforeSuite(func() { Godogs = 0 }) s.BeforeScenario(func(**messages.Pickle) { Godogs = 0 // clean the state before every scenario }) s.Step(`^there are (\d+) godogs$`, thereAreGodogs) s.Step(`^I eat (\d+)$`, iEat) s.Step(`^there should be (\d+) remaining$`, thereShouldBeRemaining) } </code></pre> <p>will be replaced by:</p> <pre><code>func InitializeTestSuite(ctx **godog.TestSuiteContext) { ctx.BeforeSuite(func() { Godogs = 0 }) } func InitializeScenario(ctx **godog.ScenarioContext) { ctx.BeforeScenario(func(**godog.Scenario) { Godogs = 0 // clean the state before every scenario }) ctx.Step(`^there are (\d+) godogs$`, thereAreGodogs) ctx.Step(`^I eat (\d+)$`, iEat) ctx.Step(`^there should be (\d+) remaining$`, thereShouldBeRemaining) } </code></pre> <h3>SuiteContext</h3> <p>The <code>SuiteContext</code> is now considered deprecated and will be removed in <code>v0.11.0</code>.</p> <h3>Concurrency Formatter</h3> <p>The <code>ConcurrencyFormatter</code> interface is now considered deprecated and will be removed in <code>v0.11.0</code>.</p> <h2>Full change log</h2> <p>See <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/godog/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#v0100">CHANGELOG.md</a>. ```</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/godog">cucumber/godog</a>

*Thread Reply:* thanks @lonnblad, I‚Äôm already going through the process of migrating to v0.11 but I‚Äôm afraid it doesn‚Äôt solve our core problem. But maybe we just want something that doesn‚Äôt make any sense.

See this playground: https://play.golang.org/p/UwMVTEiDHPg (it‚Äôs theoretically runnable, I only found out after writing it that it times out during the build, oh well)

I recreated the example from my OP. Both services reuse a common functionality simply called ‚Äúcommon‚Äù here which is stateful and registers some steps and hooks itself. Now since both services rely on this dependency it makes it not possible for serviceA to also reuse serviceB without re-registering ‚Äúcommon‚Äù (obviously). This seems like a simple issue but we haven‚Äôt been able to figure out a clean solution to this that does not result in a global variable common in common/context.go which holds the current instance of Common and a check to prevent it re-registering steps/hooks. Maybe we‚Äôre doing something completely wrong but it seems to be a normal usecase.

I assume the solution is to just have all reusable steps in common contexts which are only registered once by each runnable feature suite but I just wanted to make sure we‚Äôre not missing something obvious.

Felix Cornelius
2021-01-19 01:08:54

*Thread Reply:* if fc.response, err = http.Get(url); err != nil { return err } if your request fails to be established (e.g. timeout happens or too many redirects) and err != nil your response fc.response is nil, which would then result in a nil pointer access later.

Otherwise what often helps is to debug and check if your fc.response was populated. I sometimes also use trace steps like this I trace the last response which just dumps the content of your struct holding the information about the last response.

2: In iSendARequestToUpdateAPI you store the response on the updateFeature type but in theResponseCodeShouldEqual you try to read the field from the basicFeature type. Is the field response defined on both types?

lonnblad
2021-01-17 01:32:04

*Thread Reply:* Hey Frederic, do you mind sharing a code example? When you say trying to set the scenario name, do you mean in the feature file?

Adding fmt.Println("scenario name", s.Name) in the godogs example, like below will print the name correctly. ```func InitializeScenario(ctx *godog.ScenarioContext) { ctx.BeforeScenario(func(s *godog.Scenario) { fmt.Println("scenario name", s.Name) Godogs = 0 // clean the state before every scenario })

ctx.Step(`^there are (\d+) godogs$`, thereAreGodogs)
ctx.Step(`^I eat (\d+)$`, iEat)
ctx.Step(`^there should be (\d+) remaining$`, thereShouldBeRemaining)

}``` But if you are trying to set the scenario name in a hook, I believe that is not supported.

2021-01-17 04:16:54

Frederic G. MARAND
2021-01-17 04:23:56

*Thread Reply:* I just realized I could set the name by putting it on the Scenario / Scenario Outline line. For some reason, I was figuring that had to be empty (probably influenced by Yaml). So problem solved, thanks for looking into it.

Frederic G. MARAND
2021-01-17 04:33:40

Found it in the meantime: the name is the text after the ‚Äú:‚Äù on the Scenario[ Outline] line.

üôå goodahn
goodahn
2021-01-18 18:54:45

*Thread Reply:* It's sure that tests should not have dependencies, however, our team is still working on resolving the dependency problem. Until then, I'd like to solve this problem by arranging the order.

Frederic G. MARAND
2021-01-18 23:43:00

*Thread Reply:* When you control the order of scenarios in your test suite by creating a TestSuite to run from TestMain, you have to pass an Options struct, which contains a Randomize int64.

Frederic G. MARAND
2021-01-18 23:43:54

*Thread Reply:* If you don‚Äôt do anything, or set to 0 manually, the scenarios are not randomized. If you set it to -1, godog chooses a random seed, and for any other value, that value is used as the seed for the randomizer.

goodahn
2021-01-19 04:44:33

*Thread Reply:* @Frederic G. MARAND Thank you for the answer! What I get from your answer is below code. Is it correct? ```func TestMain(m **testing.M) { opts := godog.Options{ Format: "progress", Paths: []string{"features/feature1"}, Randomize: 0, }

godog.TestSuite{
    Name: "godogs",
    TestSuiteInitializer: InitializeTestSuite,
    ScenarioInitializer:  InitializeScenario,
    Options: &amp;opts,
}.Run()

opts = godog.Options{
    Format:    "progress",
    Paths:     []string{"features/feature2"},
    Randomize: 0,
}

godog.TestSuite{
    Name: "godogs",
    TestSuiteInitializer: InitializeTestSuite,
    ScenarioInitializer:  InitializeScenario,
    Options: &amp;opts,
}.Run()

}```

goodahn
2021-01-19 04:48:31

*Thread Reply:* @Frederic G. MARAND If the number of feature increases, I should repeat below code block. opts = ~ godog.TestSuite{ Is this what you meant?

Frederic G. MARAND
2021-01-19 07:05:43

*Thread Reply:* Normally, you use Options.Paths to list feature directories, not individual feature files, but it seems to work too, so you can just list the feature files in one opts slice, set randomize to 0, and run the suite, and you should have your features in order

Frederic G. MARAND
2021-01-19 07:10:25

*Thread Reply:* Just checked, and it appears to work, to order features (not scenarios, though): opts := godog.Options{ Format: format, Paths: []string{ "features/client2.feature", "features/client1.feature", }, Randomize: 0, } // Run the godog tests. status1 := godog.TestSuite{ Name: "godogs", TestSuiteInitializer: InitializeTestSuite, ScenarioInitializer: InitializeScenario, Options: &amp;opts, }.Run()

Frederic G. MARAND
2021-01-19 07:11:28

*Thread Reply:* From what I seen, scenarios order/randomization is within a feature, not across features.

Alex Granovsky

Hi, how I can tell to godog not to create new executable for test, but using existing one? It is to long to wait , when I just want to run some .feature one by one?

lonnblad
2021-01-25 04:45:38

*Thread Reply:* Hi Alex, the easiest way to do this is to first build a godog binary and then have it executing a specific .feature file or a specific scenario in that feature file.

If you are using v0.11.0 &gt; godog build -o godog.test &gt; ./godog.test features/some_file.feature

Viktor Rogatin

Looks like Before hooks for both Suite and Scenario are just for convince because both corresponding Initialize methods are being called exact same number of times. For scenario, there are couple of perks, like access to scenario name and id. But I wonder why not to use native context package for both test suite and Scenario contexts. Would be way easier to access properties through standard ctx.Value using some helper methods like godog.ScenarioName(ctx) . Is this something godog is moving to or am I missing something?

lonnblad
2021-02-04 09:51:35

*Thread Reply:* Hi Viktor

Yes, as of v0.10.0, those hooks are mostly for convenience and due to legacy.

Regarding the question on context, we have a few ongoing discussions regarding using the native context package and I would say that we are moving towards using that. However, since we are developing a solution which is actively used by a fairly large community, we try to reduce the amount of breaking changes we do, 2020 definitely had its share.

Personally, I would like us to design an updated API based on the context package for the Initializers, the Hooks and the Step Definitions, which then also should support Attachments.

Hello,

For feature files, any cucumer add-on may help like that one for example: https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=alexkrechik.cucumberautocomplete

For steps in the step definition, go add-on should be helpful

Outside of CucumberStudio, there are no actionwords. Actionwords are very specific to CucumberStudio, for historical reasons, and once you generate code for Cucumber Open, you won't notice any actionword anymore.

Gem
2021-05-26 13:38:07

*Thread Reply:* https://github.com/cucumber/godog/issues/335#issuecomment-666237219

<https://github.com/cucumber/godog/issues/335#issuecomment-666237219|Comment on #335 Why was BeforeFeature hook removed?>
<p>Technically your background in code is this</p> <pre><code>Turn the stove on, if it is not already on </code></pre> <p>Which would be translated to</p> <pre><code>Given I have a pre-heated stove </code></pre> <p>Then inside your step def / glue code. You would use generic coding techniques to ensure this expensive operation is only ever performed once. So inside your program thread you initialize the class or whatever is expensive, and then memoize the running of the expensive method.</p> <p>This way it doesn't matter if you run scenarios 1-&gt;7, 3-&gt;6 or just scenario 5. The stove (for each execution), will be turned on and pre-heated <strong>once</strong> only.</p> <p>If Memoization is not your thing, and you will only ever use the single stove (Which seems likely), then maybe Singletons are your thing.</p>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/godog">cucumber/godog</a>
Gem
2021-05-26 13:38:27

*Thread Reply:* Feel free to follow up with any questions you may have

Gem
2021-05-26 13:40:01

*Thread Reply:* Also, if you're keen, I think the godog project would benefit immensely from an added example implementation that illustrates this behavior! If it's able to help educate even one other person using godog that'd be a win. You're not the first or even third to ask about it.

As requested here: <https://intellij-support.jetbrains.com/hc/en-us/community/posts/360000369830-GoLand-Cucumber-Gherkin-support-for-godog> it would be great if the test runner could support Cucumber-like output from "godog" or other similar testing tools. package main import ( "fmt" "<a href="http://github.com/DATA-DOG/godog">github.com/DATA-DOG/godog</a>" ) func thereAreGodogs(available int) error { Godogs = available return nil } func iEat(num int) error { if Godogs ·ê∏ num { return fmt.Errorf("you cannot eat %d godogs, there are %d available", num, Godogs) } Godogs -= num return nil } func thereShouldBeRemaining(remaining int) error { if Godogs != remaining { return fmt.Errorf("expected %d godogs to be remaining, but there is %d", remaining, Godogs) } return nil } func FeatureContext(s *godog.Suite) { s.Step(`^there are (\d+) godogs$`, thereAreGodogs) s.Step(`^I eat (\d+)$`, iEat) s.Step(`^there should be (\d+) remaining$`, thereShouldBeRemaining) s.BeforeScenario(func(interface{}) { Godogs = 0 // clean the state before every scenario }) }‚Ä¶

Blaise Pabon
2021-12-10 06:14:25

*Thread Reply:* I straddle the python and go communities and I see a similar underlying cause in the python space. TL;DR: the community adoption of cucumber lags behind the official upstream.

Jetbrains and other vendors will tend to follow the most frequently used implementation (or rather, its API) and if that implementation does not follow upstream, then it starts to drift.

My intuition would be to bring this up with @Jo Laing and @matt-SmartBear to see if upstream can coordinate an effort to facilitate the upgrade of the native implementations, even if it means creating some kind of modularity where they can import an external library.

Ashley Kitson

Does anyone have any guidance on how to create reusable spec definitions, best practices, gotchas etc?

Gem
2021-12-16 00:16:00

*Thread Reply:* My first gut response would be that mostly depends on how you write your Gherkin itself. Resources out there on improving your feature files would probably be the first place to start.

Gherkin is meant to be expressive of the behavior of the product rather than constrained by trying to fit it into the underlying code.

Gem
2021-12-16 00:18:47

*Thread Reply:* The code level guidance I'd give is try to focus on making your step definition methods only act as orchestrators that call to helper methods. Set up those helper methods to be reusable and what actually perform the action of steps.

Gem
2021-12-16 00:19:41

*Thread Reply:* If you've got examples that you'd like to share, we can chat about them here. üôÇ As a heads up, there's also a channel specifically for #gherkin too.

Ashley Kitson
2021-12-16 00:57:58

*Thread Reply:* Hi @Gem Thanks for responding. I've used BDD extensively in the past in PHP with Behat, and my PHP devs use it currently. We are just starting with BDD & Go. In my experience with Behat, we were able to write common spec definitions and put them into a separate library and compose them into our test suites. This allowed us to rapidly develop a DSL that everyone understood and used.

A simple example:

Scenario: Happy Path Given I have valid API Logon credentials When I call the "API Logon" endpoint Then I will get a 200 HTTP status And I will receive an idToken And I will receive an API key Given I have valid API Logon credentials:

This creates an object that will be passed onto various other spec definitions.

When I call the "API Logon" endpoint:

This will be a common occurrence for testing any of our APIs. In Behat we'd encapsulate the endpoint as a Page object that knew how to call the correct url and that is injected with the credentials object. The response to the call is added to the Page object for later interrogation. The credentials object is updated with the auth headers so that calls to Pages that require authentication will be able to retrieve them and inject into the subsequent HTTP call.

Then I will get a 200 HTTP response:

The current Page is "API Logon" so this simply interrogates the current page's response for the status code.

All of the above would be in a common spec library. The rest would be specific to the test itself.

In another test suite we might write something like

Background: Given I have valid API Logon credentials And I call the "API Logon" endpoint Scenario: One ... Scenario: Two ... Another common use case is to have builders in your background clause to initialise the target system with a User that has specific characteristics, e.g. Background: Given I have a user defined: | uid | role | | <a href="mailto:foo@bar.com">foo@bar.com</a> | reader | Hope that makes sense?

Gem
2021-12-16 01:50:03

*Thread Reply:* Yep!

Gem
2021-12-16 01:50:47

*Thread Reply:* All of that is still doable in go too. üôÇ

Gem
2021-12-16 01:52:17

*Thread Reply:* The repo has an API example here that walks you through the steps. I haven't fully examined it but it should at least give you a launch pad

Gem
2021-12-16 02:05:46

*Thread Reply:* As far as the gherkin side of things go, I'd probably do things like (in the first background snippet) combine the two steps to be something like, "Given a standard user is authenticated."

It'd be a single step definition that could call to helper functions that create/obtain creds and then call the login endpoint to auth.

Another option could be to even wrap it a layer further since Gherkin should communicate what's important to the reader and business functionality. Since all the scenarios in that file will be based on an authed user, you could drop the background and have pertinent step defs handle the login behind the scenes.

Something like, When an authenticated user calls "XYZ"

This removes the incidental steps that feel like more of an automation requirement than a requirement for the business folks.

Gem

*Thread Reply:* One thing that I'd caution (in any Cucumber implementation, not just godog) is modeling/tying the Gherkin too closely to the underlying code simply for automation/dryness' sake.

This can be a slippery slope that leads to difficulty in working with the project and why some folks in the industry dislike Cucumber. It's not Cucumber's fault but since it's the tool that they were working with, it's what receives the fault. üòÖ

<p><strong>Markdown with Gherkin</strong></p> <p>Markdown with Gherkin (MDG) is a dialect of Markdown that is supported by<br /> the Gherkin parser<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/common/blob/main/gherkin/MARKDOWN_WITH_GHERKIN.md#user-content-fn-1-5219b8878f5ce2b7776d84c77c687f57">1</a>.</p> <p>MDG is a strict superset of <a href="https://github.github.com/gfm/">GitHub Flavored Markdown</a> (GFM).<br /> MDG files must use the <code>.feature.md</code> extension. This is to prevent regular <code>.md</code> files from<br /> being parsed by Gherkin, and also to provide a hint to editors.</p> <p>MDG makes it possible to embed Gherkin scenarios directly in Markdown, using<br /> conventional Markdown syntax. MDG documents can be rendered by any GFM compliant library.</p> <p>The parsing rules are as follows:</p> <p>‚Ä¢ The following keywords (and their translations) must be preceded by <em>one or more</em> <code>#</code> (Markdown header). Examples: ‚Ä¢ <code># Feature</code> ‚Ä¢ The <code># Feature</code> header is optional in MDG. If the document doesn't start with it,<br /> the first line of the document will be used as the name of the feature. ‚Ä¢ <code># Background</code> ‚Ä¢ <code># Rule</code> ‚Ä¢ <code># Scenario</code> ‚Ä¢ <code># Scenario Outline</code> ‚Ä¢ <code># Examples</code> ‚Ä¢ The following step keywords (and their translations) must be preceded by a <code>-</code> or <code>**</code> (Markdown list item). Examples: ‚Ä¢ <code>** Given</code> ‚Ä¢ <code>** When</code> ‚Ä¢ <code>** Then</code> ‚Ä¢ <code>** And</code> ‚Ä¢ <code>** But</code> ‚Ä¢ Data Tables and <code>Examples</code> tables use the <a href="https://github.github.com/gfm/#tables-extension-">GFM table</a><br /> syntax. <em>IMPORTANT:</em> In order to recognise Data Tables and Examples Tables, they have to be indented 2-5 spaces. Unindented GFM tables will not be recognised as Data Tables or Examples Tables. ‚Ä¢ Doc Strings use the <a href="https://github.github.com/gfm/#fenced-code-blocks">GFM fenced code blocks</a> syntax. ‚Ä¢ Tags must be wrapped by single <code>on each side, for example ``</code>@hello` ``, and be placed on a line <em>above</em> the keyword (as with Gherkin Classic).</p> <p><strong>Why Markdown with Gherkin</strong></p> <p>Markdown has become the de-facto standard for authoring rich text content in<br /> plain text. There is a vast ecosystem of platforms and tools that support<br /> editing and rendering of Markdown documents.</p> <p>You can create beautiful documentation with Markdown, so it makes sense to<br /> use it for <a href="https://leanpub.com/bddbooks-formulation">living documentation</a>.</p> <p>Here is a short example that illustrates the similarities and differences between<br /> classic Gherkin and MDG.</p> <p>Classic Gherkin:</p> <pre><code>Feature: Staying alive This is about actually staying alive, not the Bee Gees song. Rule: If you don't eat you die [xkcd](&lt;https://imgs.xkcd.com/comics/lunch_2x.png&gt;) @important @essential Scenario Outline: eating Given there are &amp;lt;start&amp;gt; cucumbers When I eat &amp;lt;eat&amp;gt; cucumbers Then I should have &amp;lt;left&amp;gt; cucumbers Examples: | start | eat | left | | 12 | 5 | 7 | | 20 | 5 | 15 | </code></pre> <p>Markdown with Gherkin:</p> <pre><code># Feature: Staying alive This is about actually staying alive, not the [Bee Gees song](&lt;https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I_izvAbhExY&gt;). ## Rule: If you don't eat you die [xkcd](&lt;https://imgs.xkcd.com/comics/lunch_2x.png&gt;) `@important` `@essential` ### Scenario Outline: eating ** Given there are &amp;lt;start&amp;gt; cucumbers ** When I eat &amp;lt;eat&amp;gt; cucumbers ** Then I should have &amp;lt;left&amp;gt; cucumbers #### Examples: | start | eat | left | | ----- | --- | ---- | | 12 | 5 | 7 | | 20 | 5 | 15 | </code></pre> <p>This Markdown document can be rendered beautifully by any GMF-compliant tool.</p> <p><strong>Rendering MDG with results</strong></p> <p>The &lt;../react/javascript|@cucumber/react&gt; library provides an <code>&amp;lt;MDG&amp;gt;</code> React component that<br /> renders a Markdown document with results coming from Cucumber (using &lt;../messages|Cucumber Messages&gt;).</p> <p>The rendered HTML contains the original contents from the Markdown file, with<br /> steps and scenarios coloured according to the results from the message stream.<br /> It also renders attachments from Cucumber (screenshots, videos, logs etc).</p> <p><strong>Some notes about parsing MDG</strong></p> <p>The same <code>Parser</code> class is used to parse Gherkin Classic documents and MDG documents, but<br /> they use a different <code>TokenMatcher</code> (scanner/lexer).</p> <p>The <code>GherkinInMarkdownTokenMatcher</code> will consider <em>all</em> lines that aren't recognised as a<br /> special token as <em>Empty</em>. The reason for this is that Markdown documents will typically<br /> have lines that have nothing to do with Gherkin - they are just prose.</p> <p>For this reason, the <code>GherkinDocument</code> AST will have <em>empty description properties</em>. This means<br /> that the JSON formatter will not include a <code>description</code> property for scenarios.</p> <p><strong>Footnotes</strong></p> <ol><li>Support for MDG is currently only supported in the &lt;../gherkin/javascript|@cucumber/gherkin&gt; (the JavaScript implementation), version <code>19.0.0</code> and above. The Cucumber team will gather feedback from users of <a href="https://www.npmjs.com/package/@cucumber/cucumber">@cucumber/cucumber</a> before porting MDG to other programming languages. <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/common/blob/main/gherkin/MARKDOWN_WITH_GHERKIN.md#user-content-fnref-1-5219b8878f5ce2b7776d84c77c687f57">‚Ü©Ô∏è</a></li> </ol>
<a href="https://github.com/cucumber/common">cucumber/common</a>

Zach Mandeville
2022-02-07 14:08:02

Hello! I was wondering if people had advice on the best ways to run a godog test suite multiple times.

For example, I am testing a service that can have different setup configurations, to be configured by the test runner. I would like to run my test suite against each of the specified configurations.

The way I am doing it now is to have a wrapper program to handle setting up the test suite and server, and then literally running the suite multiple times within this wrapper. It works well so far, though it means that I am getting multiple test summaries to stdout. It would be good to be able to combine all the tests results into a single ending summary. Has anyone else had a scenario similar to this, and recommendations on how to approach it?

Thank you!

Felix Cornelius
2022-02-14 03:56:39

*Thread Reply:* how would these "setup configurations" look like? I suppose you're changing internal configurations of the service and you want to see how it behaves when you run the same test suite, before and after the change.

If it's already possible to configure the service that is called by the test-runner, then why not create different scenarios, one for each configuration. You could introduce a custom step that prepares the service configuration you want and use it e.g. as a Given step in the beginning of your scenario. Then you run all these scenarios, e.g. by giving them the same tag, and you'll get a combined output summary of all scenarios.

More questions üôÇ Sry guys, didn't found anything in docs and API reference. Let's say, I have a Gherkin .feature file with "Examples:" table, we usually used in order to write more data, so test-cases are also abit data-driven. Example: Scenario Outline: Client endpoint test CREATE Given I make JSON body for Clients: &lt;arg1&gt;, &lt;arg2&gt;, &lt;arg3&gt;, &lt;arg4&gt; When I send a PUT request to "endpoint" Then I get response with status code 200 and Client info: &lt;arg1&gt;, &lt;arg2&gt;, &lt;arg3&gt;, &lt;arg4&gt; Examples: | arg1 | arg2 | arg3 | arg4 | | loremIpsumDolor | lorem_ipsumDolor | lorem_ipsum | stringNumbers | What should I write in stepDefinitionFile in order to hook godog.ScenarioContext with feature file? In Java it would be something like: "I make JSON body for Clients: {}, {}, {}, {}" Here, in godog I have tried to write: ^I make JSON body for Clients: "([^"]**)", "([^"]**)", "([^"]**)", "([^"]**)"$ It fails - this expression is not working... Full line: ctx.Step(`^I make JSON body for Clients: "([^"]**)", "([^"]**)", "([^"]**)", "([^"]**)"$`, api.iMakeJSONBody) Snippet is telling me to write 2x separate lines, this means that I can't really change the data in feature file, without changing the code: ctx.Step(^I make JSON body for Clients: loremIpsumDolor2, loremipsumDolor2, loremipsum2, stringNumbers2$, iMakeJSONBody) ctx.Step(^I make JSON body for Clients: loremIpsumDolor, loremipsumDolor, loremipsum, stringNumbers$, iMakeJSONBody)

How are you actually working with Examples: table? Or it is not supported at all? For me now it looks half-broken...

Sorry - not broken))) Found solution again. You actually need to put arguments in semicolon, like this: Scenario Outline: Client endpoint test CREATE Given I make JSON body for Clients: "&lt;arg1&gt;", "&lt;arg2&gt;", "&lt;arg3&gt;", "&lt;arg4&gt;" When I send a PUT request to "endpoint" Then I get response with status code 200 and Client info: "&lt;arg1&gt;", "&lt;arg2&gt;", "&lt;arg3&gt;", "&lt;arg4&gt;" Examples: | arg1 | arg2 | arg3 | arg4 | | loremIpsumDolor | lorem_ipsumDolor | lorem_ipsum | stringNumbers | | loremIpsumDolor2 | lorem_ipsumDolor2 | lorem_ipsum2 | stringNumbers2 | Again - documentation doesn't say anything about that)) Definitely it needs some examples with this table. Very commonly used in Gherkin. üôÇ Thank you for attention!

*Thread Reply:* Table arguments don't necessarily need to be put in quotes, the issue was just that in your regex you had them quoted: "([^"]**)" . If you remove the quotes from your regex, it works like you initially tried with Given I make JSON body for Clients: &lt;arg1&gt;, &lt;arg2&gt;, &lt;arg3&gt;, &lt;arg4&gt;

NIKHITA Y
2022-02-22 15:56:57

Hello everyone! I am trying to see if there is a way in godog to retry (re-run) scenarios automatically in case of failure.

Felix Cornelius
2022-02-25 09:13:01

*Thread Reply:* Hey! Cucumber scenarios should ideally always have a deterministic outcome, so rerunning them should always yield the same result as on the initial run, just like unit tests. Maybe your scenarios are flaky? Why do you expect your scenarios to succeed after retrying a failed one?

To your question: this is not supported by godog out of the box (for above reasons). If you really need to, you could run the features programmatically with godog.TestSuite{...}.Run() and redo so depending on the output of Run().

2022-03-02 06:47:42

vearutop
2022-05-25 01:35:28

hello folks, please vote/share your ideas on https://github.com/cucumber/godog/discussions/478

<https://github.com/cucumber/godog/discussions/478|#478 Deprecation of `godog` CLI>
<p>Historically <code>godog</code> started as a command-line tool that you can run in your project and it would parse your code and build test executor. This seems convenient at first, but comes with limitations.</p> <p>Whenever you need something more than running tests (build tags, debugger, test coverage, etc...) you may find lack of control or difficult configuration. This comes from an unfortunate fact that <code>godog</code> CLI takes ownership of some responsibilities that are usually carried out by <code>go</code> tools, those features are rich and it is not feasible to keep up parity.</p> <p>It is possible (and recommended) to run <code>godog</code> feature tests as <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/godog#subtests-of-testingt">subtests of <code>**testing.T</code></a>, this mode of operation aims to deliver same functionality as <code>godog run</code> with standard <code>go test</code> (and therefore all advanced Go features available too with IDE assistance).</p> <p>In a <a href="https://github.com/orgs/cucumber/teams/committers/discussions/7?from_comment=8#discussion-7-comment-8">recent discussion</a> there was an idea to deprecate and phase out <code>godog</code> CLI to reduce complexity and maintenance effort.</p> <p>I would like to learn from community if <code>godog</code> in CLI mode is still useful these days. Please vote and share your use cases for <code>godog run/build</code> that do not translate well into <code>go test</code> operation.</p> <p>Thank you for using <code>godog</code>! ‚ù§Ô∏è</p> <p>Relevant issues:<br /> <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/godog/issues/154">#154</a> <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/godog/issues/373">#373</a> <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/godog/issues/325">#325</a> <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/godog/issues/159">#159</a></p>

*Thread Reply:* I haven't used the Go port of the HOCON library - https://github.com/gurkankaymak/hocon, but I have used the original JVM implementation when I was doing a lot of scala, and it was really useful in some of the tests I was maintaining. Brian Hnat
2022-06-21 06:47:50

*Thread Reply:* I don't have a project I can share - I've only used it at work. But I can try to answer some questions you might have. At a high level, I've used it when using TestMain (there are discussions about deprecating the separate godog cli, so using godog with go test would probably be a better place to start, regardless of using testcontainers-go). The overall approach was like this: ```func TestMain(m **testing.M) { exitCode := run(m) os.Exit(exitCode) }

type mysqlDBContainer struct { testcontainers.Container URI string }

func run(m **testing.M) int { ctx := context.Background() mysqlContainer, err := setupMysqlContainer(ctx, logger) if err != nil { // handle here }

defer mysqlContainer.Container.Terminate(ctx)

// perform any DB migrations here
// perform any other setup before all the tests run here, and defer any teardown

return m.Run()

}

func setupMysqlContainer(ctx context.Context) (**mysqlDBContainer, error) { req := testcontainers.ContainerRequest{ Image: "mysql:8.0", ExposedPorts: []string{"3306/tcp", "33060/tcp"}, Env: map[string]string{ "MYSQLROOTPASSWORD": dbPassword, "MYSQL_DATABASE": dbName, }, WaitingFor: wait.ForLog("port: 3306 MySQL Community Server - GPL"), }

mysqlC, err := testcontainers.GenericContainer(ctx, testcontainers.GenericContainerRequest{
    ContainerRequest: req,
    Started:          true,
})
if err != nil {
    return nil, err
}
host, err := mysqlC.Host(ctx)
if err != nil {
    return nil, err
}
port, err := mysqlC.MappedPort(ctx, "3306")
if err != nil {
        return nil, err
}
url := fmt.Sprintf("%s:%s@tcp(%s:%s)/%s?parseTime=true", dbUsername, dbPassword, host, port.Port(), dbName)
return &amp;mysqlDBContainer{mysqlC, url}, nil

}`` I created the separaterunfunction, because when the os.Exit is called, it exits immediately and doesn't execute the deferred code. So I separate that out from TestMain, and the deferred tear down does get executed at the end of therun` function.

Depending on how you have things structured, you could use the short flag (https://pkg.go.dev/testing#hdr-Skipping) to not start up the DB containers when you're just running unit tests. So then your TestMain might look something like: func TestMain(m **testing.M) { flag.Parse() if testing.Short() { exitCode:= m.Run() os.Exit(exitCode) } exitCode := run(m) os.Exit(exitCode) } The godog setup can be in the same file as TestMain, or separate. You could also check testing.Short() in this function if you wanted skip the features when only running unit tests. func TestFeatures(t **testing.T) { suite := godog.TestSuite{ // setup here } if suite.Run() != 0 { // handle here } } The other approach that teams I've been on have used (for a gRPC service) is to utilize a make file and docker-compose to start the DB container, and then run the tests from another container. I had to use https://github.com/ufoscout/docker-compose-wait to hold off on starting my tests until the mysql container was accepting connections (the same thing the WaitingFor parameter will handle in testcontainers-go). We had to specify --exit-code-from &lt;our app's test container&gt; in the docker-compose call in the make file. It all worked, but there was way more setup involved (creating the docker-compose file, creating the Dockerfile for the app's test container, creating the makefile). I'd say the advantage to that was I could start a mysql container locally and run my tests repeatedly locally without having to restart the DB container each time vs testcontainers would start/stop the db when I ran go test. But there was certainly a lot more set up w/ the docker-compose approach, and I also wound up mounting volumes in our CircleCI instance to our test container, so we could publish test results and code coverage files. I'm not sure all the extra setup w/ the docker-compose approach really brought a big benefit that offset the additional setup.

pkg.go.dev
testing package - testing - Go Packages
Package testing provides support for automated testing of Go packages.
Original URL: https://pkg.go.dev/testing#hdr-Skipping
ufoscout/docker-compose-wait
A simple script to wait for other docker images to be started while using docker-compose

*Thread Reply:* https://github.com/cucumber/godog/pull/476 this PR is related, I'll try to review/suggest API changes (if any) next week

<https://github.com/cucumber/godog/pull/476|#476 add new option for created features with parsing from byte slices>
<p>Hello! In my work we are trying to build in a pre-processor for our feature files so we can have some dynamic feature generation when running our tests. I made this for us to use but though maybe it could be interesting for more people than just us. I've added another option to define custom features to be used in the suite, and then added an interface to pass in a map[string][]byte representing the path/read contents from the file (in our case, the contents after doing preprocessing). I think this implementation is maybe not fully working since it seems to be missing the line filtering, but other than that I think I've got all the other inner workings there. Just wanted to submit it if it could be interesting for anyone!</p> <p>Leave me a comment if you think this is a good idea and then I can try adding some testing/additional documentation</p> <p><strong>ü§î What's changed?</strong> <strong>‚ö° What's your motivation?</strong> <strong>üè∑Ô∏è What kind of change is this?</strong></p> <p>‚Ä¢ üè¶ Refactoring/debt/DX (improvement to code design, tooling, documentation etc. without changing behaviour) ‚Ä¢ üêõ Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes a defect) ‚Ä¢ ‚ö° New feature (non-breaking change which adds new behaviour) ‚Ä¢ üí• Breaking change (incompatible changes to the API)</p> <p><strong>‚ôªÔ∏è Anything particular you want feedback on?</strong> <strong>üìã Checklist:</strong></p> <p>‚òëÔ∏é I agree to respect and uphold the <a href="https://cucumber.io/conduct/">Cucumber Community Code of Conduct</a> ‚òê I've changed the behaviour of the code ‚òê I have added/updated tests to cover my changes. ‚òê My change requires a change to the documentation. ‚òê I have updated the documentation accordingly. ‚òê Users should know about my change ‚òê I have added an entry to the "Unreleased" section of the &lt;../CHANGELOG.md|<strong>CHANGELOG</strong>&gt;, linking to this pull request.</p> <hr /> <p><em>This text was originally generated from a <a href="https://docs.github.com/en/communities/using-templates-to-encourage-useful-issues-and-pull-requests/about-issue-and-pull-request-templates">template</a>, then edited by hand. <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/.github/edit/main/.github/PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE.md">You can modify the template here.</a></em></p>

Brian Hnat
2022-11-10 05:03:12

In godog's TestSuite, there's a TestSuiteInitializer parameter. You can set some logic there in a BeforeSuite or AfterSuite hook. func IntializeTestSuite(sc **godog.TestSuiteContext) { sc.BeforeSuite(func() { // .... }) sc.AfterSuite(func() { // .... }) } suite := godog.TestSuite{ TestSuiteInitializer: IntializeTestSuite, ..... }

Miroslav Sommer

üëã Hi all! I‚Äôve submitted an article for discussion about using stretchr/testigy and godog. Would love your feedback. It seems difficult. It can be done. Can we make it easier?

#535 Using assert or require from stretchr/testify in godog
<p>Hi all!</p> <p>This has been bogging me for a while; why we cannot simply use <code>assert</code> and <code>require</code> funcs in the BDD steps funcs?</p> <p><strong>TL;DR</strong></p> <p>It can be done with very little of boilerplate and it's not difficult at all. I wish this was built-in into godog and available via some kind of a flag, or property in the suite setup.</p> <p>I've put together some analysis with some proposals.</p> <hr /> <p>More below‚Ä¶</p> <p>I've looked <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/godog/blob/main/_examples/assert-godogs/godogs_test.go">here</a> and <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/questions/61180950/using-an-assertion-library-with-godog-test-framework">here</a> for some ideas.</p> <p>Happy to be told this has been discussed before, rejected, disregarded, or anything else, but I haven't really found much useful about this topic anywhere. It's kinda big deal to me, possibly a blocker from using <code>godog</code> professionally on very large projects.</p> <p>Seems like there are a couple of obvious reasons for this <em>issue</em>:</p> <p><strong>How to get access to the <code>**testing.T</code> instance?</strong></p> <blockquote> <p>As a developer<br /> I want easy built-in access to the **testing.T instance within my test suite (godog test steps specifically)<br /> So that I can use the assert module, write less code, spend less time doing so, and thus save money</p> </blockquote> <p>This seems to be an easy one. We can use the test struct pattern as described e.g. in the <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/godog/blob/main/_examples/api/api_test.go">API example</a>:</p> <pre><code>type apiFeature struct { resp **httptest.ResponseRecorder } ‚Ä¶ func (a **apiFeature) theResponseCodeShouldBe(code int) error { if code != a.resp.Code { return fmt.Errorf("expected response code to be: %d, but actual is: %d", code, a.resp.Code) } return nil } </code></pre> <p>‚Ä¶ and add the <code>**testing.T</code> field to it. That way it would be easily accessible in all steps:</p> <pre><code>type apiFeature struct { t **testing.T // &lt;= HERE resp **httptest.ResponseRecorder } ‚Ä¶ func (a **apiFeature) theResponseCodeShouldBe(code int) { assert.Equal(a.t, code, a.resp.Core, fmt.Sprintf("expected response code to be: %d, but actual is: %d", code, a.resp.Code)) } </code></pre> <p>ü§î IMHO, this is the pattern I would like to see being supported Out-Of-the-Box or even suggested by default. The default pattern seems to be the one using global variables (yuck‚Ä¶ probably for simplicity?) or passing values between steps via the context (yucky too, but that's for a separate discussion‚Ä¶ I'm sure there were reasons).</p> <p>Note the difference to the original code - it's now much cleaner, less code.</p> <p>But there's a gotcha. üöß</p> <p><strong>Assertion funcs like <code>assert.Equal</code> return a bool and not an error.</strong></p> <p>The <code>theResponseCodeShouldBe</code> does not return an <code>error</code> anymore and therefore the error from the assertion is somewhat swallowed and this step would actually <strong>PASS</strong> even in cases where it should <strong>FAIL</strong>. The <code>godog</code> test statistics would show happily something like <strong>3 scenarios (3 passed, 0 failed)</strong> even if a step was failing. It may just log an error in the output. <em>Not good.</em></p> <p>Workaround: We could put the <code>error</code> return type back at the expense of more code:</p> <pre><code>func (a **apiFeature) theResponseCodeShouldBe(code int) error { if !assert.Equal(a.t, code, a.resp.Core, fmt.Sprintf("expected response code to be: %d, but actual is: %d", code, a.resp.Code)) { return fmt.Errorf("expected response code to be: %d, but actual is: %d", code, a.resp.Code) } return nil } </code></pre> <p>Yucky ;-) This is obviously very na√Øve, with a duplicated code and should be refactored - producing even more code. I'm not going there‚Ä¶</p> <p>Another example - loosely following the example from the <a href="https://github.com/cucumber/godog">godog homepage</a>:</p> <pre><code>func thereShouldBeRemaining(ctx context.Context, remaining int) error { available, ok := ctx.Value(godogsCtxKey{}).(int) if !ok { return errors.New("there are no godogs available") } if available != remaining { return fmt.Errorf("expected %d godogs to be remaining, but there is %d", remaining, available) } return nil } </code></pre> <p>With the pattern supporting <code>assert</code> (and <code>require</code>), we would save so much code and make it even more readable!</p> <pre><code>type testContext struct { t **testing.T available int } func (ctx **testContext) thereShouldBeRemaining(remaining int) { require.NotEmpty(t, ctx.available, "there are no godogs available") assert.Equal(t, ctx.available, remaining, fmt.Sprintf("expected %d godogs to be remaining, but there is %d", remaining, g.available)) } </code></pre> <p>From 12 lines of code down to 5 (for the step func, including an empty line). I call that success!</p> <p><strong>But it doesn't work‚Ä¶</strong></p> <p>Yeah. I've tried to sum up and visually show the issues on <a href="https://github.com/mirogta/godog-assert/tree/assert-does-not-work-with-godog">this branch</a>.</p> <p><strong>Patterns used:</strong></p> <p>‚Ä¢ Test values always passed via a strongly-typed test context struct. ‚Ä¢ This test context struct embeds another struct which provides access to **testing.T</p> <p>See</p> <p>‚Ä¢ <a href="https://github.com/mirogta/godog-assert/blob/assert-does-not-work-with-godog/features/godogs.feature">feature file</a> with 3 scenarios ‚Ä¢ the 1st scenario should PASS ‚úÖ ‚Ä¢ the 2nd scenario should FAIL due to a failing assert, but it's passing ‚ùå ‚Ä¢ the 3rd scenario should FAIL due to invalid pre-condition (using <code>require</code>) even before it gets to the assert - this is failing but the output is still "green" and not "red" ‚ùì ‚Ä¢ <a href="https://github.com/mirogta/godog-assert/blob/assert-does-not-work-with-godog/godogs_test.go">test</a> ‚Ä¢ <a href="https://github.com/mirogta/godog-assert/blob/assert-does-not-work-with-godog/output.txt">textual output</a> ‚Ä¢ <a href="https://github.com/mirogta/godog-assert/blob/assert-does-not-work-with-godog/output.png">colorised output</a> - as you can see, it's all nice and green (not good) and only the last scenario is failing. The second scenario is shown as PASS (not good). I've highlighted the problematic areas with red boxes for you.</p> <p><strong>Is there a fix?</strong></p> <p>You be the judge üòâ With the ideas shared in the links at the top and the above <em>issues</em>, I've tried to come up with a proof-of-concept to fix them.</p> <p><strong>Patterns used:</strong></p> <p>‚Ä¢ Test values always passed via a strongly-typed test context struct. ‚Ä¢ This test context struct contains another struct <code>bt **BddTesting</code> which handles failures (from <code>require</code>) and errors (from <code>assert</code>).</p> <p>What is <code>BddTesting</code>?</p> <p>‚Ä¢ Wrapper around <code>t **testing.T</code> and potential errors ‚Ä¢ Used in place of the <code>t</code> in assertion funcs, e.g. <code>assert.Equal(t, ‚Ä¶)</code> would become <code>assert.Equal(bt, ‚Ä¶)</code> ‚Ä¢ Assertions from <code>assert</code> are tracked as errors, so that we get correct statistics and color-coding ‚Ä¢ Pre-conditions from <code>require</code> are tracked as failures, but unlike the original <code>t **testing.T</code> module it's using <code>t.Fail()</code> and <strong>not</strong> <code>t.FailNow()</code>, so that we always get the overall test suite stats.</p> <p>See</p> <p>‚Ä¢ <a href="https://github.com/mirogta/godog-assert/blob/main/features/godogs.feature">feature file</a> is the same one with 3 scenarios ‚Ä¢ the 1st scenario should PASS ‚úÖ ‚Ä¢ the 2nd scenario should FAIL due to a failing assert ‚úÖ ‚Ä¢ the 3rd scenario should FAIL due to invalid pre-condition (using <code>require</code>) even before it gets to the assert ‚úÖ ‚Ä¢ <a href="https://github.com/mirogta/godog-assert/blob/main/godogs_test.go">test</a> ‚Ä¢ <a href="https://github.com/mirogta/godog-assert/blob/main/output.txt">textual output</a> ‚Ä¢ <a href="https://github.com/mirogta/godog-assert/blob/main/output.png">colorised output</a> - as you can see, all stats are correct and all failed steps are in red with the errors explaining the problems</p> <p><strong>Is it done? Can I use it now?</strong></p> <p>No, not quite.</p> <p>There's a little issue with some duplicated output. It's currently too chatty. There's work to be done. If you know how to fix it, please feel free to raise a PR :-)</p> <p>This is only a PoC and intended as a starting point for a discussion on how to make better use of <code>assert</code> and <code>require</code> effectively in <code>godog</code>.</p> <p>So why not use <https://github.com/cucumber/godog/blob/main/<em>examples/assert-godogs/godogs</em>test.go|as‚Ä¶</p>

vearutop
2023-05-16 03:26:01

*Thread Reply:* there are two approaches to share state between steps and scenarios (shared state is something to be careful about, as it may lead to degraded tests portability and more flakiness)

‚Ä¢ you can use steps container or a global variable to keep state (https://github.com/cucumber/godog/blob/v0.12.6/_examples/godogs/godogs_test.go#L57, https://github.com/cucumber/godog/blob/v0.12.6/_examples/db/api_test.go#L64), this approach may be tricky to get right with concurrency enabled ‚Ä¢ you can receive and return ctx context.Context to pass state down the scenario (https://github.com/godogx/vars/blob/v0.1.6/steps.go#L91), this approach works well with concurrency since each scenario starts with its own context

vearutop
2023-12-20 11:22:15

*Thread Reply:* hello, godog cli had suggested step definition signatures and this still works in **testing.T mode

here is an example:

  1. in a Go module (can be a new empty like in this example)
  2. create features/test.feature with contents ```Feature: A new test

Scenario: Some action

When I had 1 godogs
And I add 5 godogs
Then I have 6 godogs```

  1. create a minimal test file features_test.go with contents ```package godog_new

import ( "testing"

"<a href="http://github.com/cucumber/godog">github.com/cucumber/godog</a>"

)

func TestFeatures(t **testing.T) { s := godog.TestSuite{}

if s.Run() != 0 {
    t.Fail()
}

}```

  1. run go test and have the suggestions ```go test

Feature: A new test

Scenario: Some action # features/test.feature:3 When I had 1 godogs And I add 5 godogs Then I have 6 godogs

1 scenarios (1 undefined) 3 steps (3 undefined) 216.679¬µs

You can implement step definitions for undefined steps with these snippets:

func iAddGodogs(arg1 int) error { return godog.ErrPending }

func iHadGodogs(arg1 int) error { return godog.ErrPending }

func iHaveGodogs(arg1 int) error { return godog.ErrPending }

func InitializeScenario(ctx **godog.ScenarioContext) { ctx.Step(^I add (\d+) godogs$, iAddGodogs) ctx.Step(^I had (\d+) godogs$, iHadGodogs) ctx.Step(^I have (\d+) godogs$, iHaveGodogs) }

PASS ok godog-new 0.346s```

  1. update your features_test.go with suggestions ```package godog_new

import ( "testing"

"<a href="http://github.com/cucumber/godog">github.com/cucumber/godog</a>"

)

func TestFeatures(t **testing.T) { s := godog.TestSuite{} s.ScenarioInitializer = InitializeScenario

if s.Run() != 0 {
    t.Fail()
}

}

func iAddGodogs(arg1 int) error { return godog.ErrPending }

func iHadGodogs(arg1 int) error { return godog.ErrPending }

func iHaveGodogs(arg1 int) error { return godog.ErrPending }

func InitializeScenario(ctx **godog.ScenarioContext) { ctx.Step(^I add (\d+) godogs$, iAddGodogs) ctx.Step(^I had (\d+) godogs$, iHadGodogs) ctx.Step(^I have (\d+) godogs$, iHaveGodogs) }```

  1. run test again go test ```Feature: A new test

Scenario: Some action # features/test.feature:3 When I had 1 godogs # featurestest.go:23 -> godog-new.iHadGodogs TODO: write pending definition And I add 5 godogs # featurestest.go:19 -> godog-new.iAddGodogs Then I have 6 godogs # features_test.go:27 -> godog-new.iHaveGodogs

1 scenarios (1 pending) 3 steps (1 pending, 2 skipped) 284.544¬µs PASS ok godog-new 0.408s```

vearutop
2023-12-20 11:25:55

*Thread Reply:* you can use deprecated godog cli in step 3 instead of creating minimal feature_test.go, but then you need to create a Go file for scenario initialiser anyway

go test mode of operation is recommended, because it does not take building ownership from the standard go tooling and therefore have better support with IDEs and compilation options
